Ra'am has lived in the first level of Undermountain for many decades. It's perfected a means of siphoning a fraction of a willing creature's soul, allowing it to create more mutually beneficial, or at least less damning, contracts.
Its presence remains little-known for it wishes it to be so. Each contract forged includes a non-disclosure clause preventing the signer from mentioning Ra'am or how their items became enchanted.
Any creature who meets Ra'am is obligated to sign a non-disclosure pact if they wish to leave its presence with their lives.

entries.name: Soul Forging
entries: An item may have at most 1 infernal blessing. That blessing may be transfered to another item for a modest fee (500gp)

An infernal blessing (Infernal weapon, not Magical) makes a weapon count as magical for the sake of resistances, etc, but the weapon's magical status is not changed for the purposes of enchantment, infusions, and so forth.

Ra'am's primary business is that of enchanting weapons (or other items) with the souls of their weilders. He takes half the sacrificed attribute as payment, and as such, if a creature can negotiate another form of payment, the attribute cost is halved.

The process of the forging is a gruesome one. First, Ra'am summons a parchment and uses his finger to write in fire the contract: The boon, the bane, and the non-disclosure pact. It attains consent from the signer, then slashes open their palm with one of its claws. The signer must then press their palm into the bottom of the contract, sealing the pact. (1 hit die damage)

After the signing, Ra'am speaks an incantation while pouring the signer's blood onto the item. He proceeds to call a lemure into the chamber, which is then shriveled to death as the hammer begins to glow. In a blinding flash, Ra'am strikes the item with the soulforger, completing the pact.

entries.name: Drug
entries: Drugs are consumed substances which yield some sort of perceived benefit and a drawback, often these are akin to poisons which have been prepared in such a way to have a desirable effect.

Drugs are often illegal, carrying legal penalties based on the type and amount carried. While most drugs carry minor penalties such as a night or tenday in jail in addition to confiscation of illicit substances, some drugs, often magical in nature, are deemed exceedingly dangerous, and their carriers may face more severe punishments such as hard labor, exile, or even death.

Common drugs such as tobacco and alcohol are fully legal. Other slightly more exotic though mostly harmless drugs such as the halfling's pipeweed are rarely prosecuted, treated more as a game of not getting caught than the law, with the only penalty being confiscation of carried drugs.
While drugs are addictive, this is difficult to portray in a ttrpg. As such, any effects of addiction are to be made through rp rather than mechanical impact.

item.name: Kraken Ink
entries: A vial of deep indigo fluid, Kraken ink is dangerous to acquire, and is heavily restricted in most civilized lands.

Upon consuming kraken ink, a creature loses all memory and knowledge of magic. This effect varies from person to person, but in general varies inversely with the amount of magical power one possesses.

While under the effects of kraken ink, a creature must make a DC 15 Wis save in order to submit to be "willing" for spells and magical effects, to include being targeted by cure wounds and similar. In addition, they have advantage on mental saving throws against spells and magical effects, and are unable to cast spells or use other magic of their own, such as a paladin's lay on hands.

When the effects of the ink wear off, all knowledge and memory of magic - EXCEPT for memories of magic which occurred within 24hr prior to ingesting the ink - returns. This duration increases to a tenday for casters with access to spells of 3rd level or higher.

The effects persist for one day for laypeople and casters whose highest spell level is 1. Those with a spell level of 2 suffer the effects for a tenday. A spell level of 3 suffer the effects for a month and 4 for 3 months. Those with access to 5th level spells suffer the effects for 5 months, 6 for 7 months. 7 for 9 months, 8 for 10 months, and 9 for a full year.
Oftentimes more paranoid or less scrupulous high power magic users will have Contingencies in place for such magical memory loss, causing Ink to be a nuissance rather than a catastrophic danger.

item.name: Runestone Lock
entries: A runestone lock is a square panel of runestones which respond to being pressed.
The puzzle gets progressively harder with attempts to manipulate the runes, but resets daily at dawn.
Once all runestones hold the same rune, the puzzle is solved, and the lock is sprung. Once the mechanism is shut, the runes reshuffle.
For one action, a creature may sequentially press 3 runes.
Prior to any rune press, a creature may make an Arcana check. On a successful check the pressed rune has no side-effects, only switching its own symbol.
On a failed arcana check, the creature may press the rune with side-effects, or may simply make no press, either way it counts as one of the three.
The Arcana DC starts at 12. Whenever an arcana check is failed, the DC increases by 4. Whenever it is passed, the DC increases by 2. The DC resets to 12 daily at dawn.

item.name: Soulforger
entries: A creature is proficient with Soulforger iff it is attuned to it.
A creature may attune Soulforger if it is evil. Otherwise, it may permanently lose 1 hit die to attune to Soulforger.
Soulforger has a magical +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls

item.name: Alcohol
entries: Alcohol is a common drug consumed by drinking it. It comes in various forms, and is revered by several of the racial and national cultures of the realms.
Alcohol is completely legal in Waterdeep.

When imbibing an alcoholic beverage, a Con save may be requested, with the DC dependent on the specific beverage and quantity. Most beer for example won't require a save unless drunk in large quantities
Passing the save increases future alcohol DCs by 1 for the next hour
Failing the save incurs 1 stack of "Intoxication", plus an additional stack for each 5 points you fail the save by.

rows: You become more friendly and less sociably inhibited - No mechanical impact
You begin to disregard feelings of safety - +2 to saving throws against being {@condition frightened}, -1 to all other saving throws
You become clumsy as the alcohol impacts your fine motor skills - -2 to Dex, to a minimum of 3.
You become more intoxicated - Additional +2 to saving throws against being {@condition frightened}, additional -2 to dex (to a min of 3)
You are now fully intoxicated - You are {@condition poisoned}.
There is no appreciable increase in your intoxication.
You become further intoxicated - Disadvantage on all saving throws.
You fall unconscious for 10 minutes, after which your intoxication level decreases by 1.
The duration of your unconsciousness increases to 1 hour, when it has elapsed to 10 minutes remaining, reduce your intoxication level by 1.
The duration of your unconsciousness increases to 8 hours, when it has elapsed to 1 hour remaining, reduce your intoxication level by 1.
The duration of your unconsciousness increases to 1 day, when it has elapsed to 8 hours remaining, reduce your intoxication level by 1.
Death

entries: All stacks of intoxication are removed upon the completion of a long rest, at which point you lose 1 hit die per stack removed (maximum reduction to 0 hit dice available)
Alcohol is made with Brewer's Supplies

item.name: Tobacco
entries: Tobacco is a common drug which is consumed in a variety of ways, though usually by smoking it.
Tobacco is completely legal in Waterdeep.

The short term effects of tobacco are insignificant enough as to have no mechanical impact. While long-term smokers often develop breathing problems, and chewers often develop significant dental issues, these are outside the scope of most campaign durations, and can be remedied with magic.
Tobacco is prepared with an herbalist's kit

item.name: Halfling Pipeweed
entries: Pipeweed is a mildly uncommon alternative to tobacco used primarily by halflings. It is used exclusively by smoking: most often in a pipe, though some younger halflings roll it into cigarettes as well.
While illegal, the only penalty is confiscation, and most halflings pass it off as tobacco to watchmen who don't feel like dealing with petty drug charges.
1 dose of pipeweed costs 2 dragons, sold either in individual, burnable packets, or in small bulk pouches.
Smoking a dose of pipeweed takes 1 action, and the effects last for 1 hour, with optional DC 15 Con saves to end the effects early every 5 minutes (including when used).
Pipeweed pacifies the user to an astonishing degree. While stoned, a creature has disadvantage on all attack rolles, and all saving throws that creature causes to be made are made at advantage.
Additionally, while stoned, a creature is immune to the {@condition frightened} and {@condition charmed} conditions.
Due to the pacifying properties as well as resiliency granted against mind altering magicks, halfling political gatherings are often filled with a haze of pipeweed smoke.
Pipeweed is prepareed with an herbalist's kit

item.name: Dust of Speed
entries: Dust of Speed is an exotic and dangerous semi-magical drug, often used by bolder members of the criminal underworld.
Due to the danger of use, Dust of Speed is highly illegal, carrying a penalty of 1 month of hard labor and imprisonment.
Dust of speed is sold in small, light blue pellets, which are crushed together then snorted to use. Each pellet costs 5 suns.

As a bonus action, crush a number of dust pellets between your fingers then snort them. You become high for a number of rounds equal to the number of pellets crushed (counting the turn in which it is used).
While high on Dust of Speed, you may take an additional bonus action on each of your turns.
Dust of Speed is a compound based on the semi-magical Blasting Powder used in firearms and cannons.
As part of the bonus action used to snort the pellets, you take an amount of damage as the dust explodes as it goes through your system, based on the number of pellets used.
This damage may not be reduced in any way
If you use Dust of Speed while already high on Dust of Speed, you gain no benefits, but still take the appropriate amount of damage.
L in the following calculations indicates your character's level. For NPCs this is their number of hit dice.

entries: Dust of Speed is made with Alchemist's Supplies and a 2nd level spell slot per pellet. (the spell slot accounts for 20gp of the pellet's market value)

item.name: Potion of Augmented Healing
entries: This potion is similar to a normal healing potion, but with more potency, and fewer painkillers.

When consumed, the consuming creature regains 4d4+4 hp, then makes a Con save against a DC equal to the amount healed. On a failed save they are Stunned by the pain caused by rapid tissue growth until the start of their next turn.
Basic Crafting Formula:

items: 40gp alchemical/medicinal ingredients
2 days downtime

entries: Over the 2 days, you grind, steep, mix, and filter the ingredients, in conjunction with various rituals and incantations performed at specific intervals. This process requires alchemists tools, or an herbalism kit with a DC 12 Wisdom (herbalism kit) check.

item.name: Potion of Gravitation
entries: This vial of blue fluid is rather peculiar in that its contents does not seem to be affected by gravity, simply floating in whatever direction it's bumped.
When consumed, the consuming creature gains magical control of its relationship with gravity, granting the following benefits:

items: At any time on your turn, you may reverse the effect of gravity on you. In this case, instantly begin falling at the normal rate upwards instead of downwards (or downwards if already affected by this). Remember that the maximum distance fallen in one turn is 500 feet. This does not count as intentional for the sake of fall damage (thus the first 10 feet are still included in damage).
As a bonus action when you jump, you may quickly flip gravity's effect on you twice, tripling your jump distance.
As a reaction to falling, you may quickly flip gravity's effect on you twice, halving the fall damage. (If you take 0 damage from a fall, you do not fall prone unless otherwise specified)

entries: These effects persist for 10 minutes, or until an effect that dispels or negates magic is applied to the user.
Basic Crafting Formula:

items: 25bxp
2 week downtime
1 1st level spell slot/day
50gp of alchemical ingredients

entries: Over the 2 weeks, you perform rituals and incantations, grind and mix the ingredients, and infuse them with magical power, gradually eroding their relationship with gravity, until left with a fine powder on the last day which is completely unaffected by gravity. The final step then combines this with water or an oil with a final infusion granting it the ability to impart its magical properties on the consumer. This process requires alchemists tools.

item.name: Chitin Slime
entries: This small jar of slime fungus can be applied to a creature as an action.

The slime quickly grows over the creature's skin, hardening into a pliable yet incredibly resilient chitin shell. The creature gains a natural armor AC calculation option of 16, and counts as being unarmored unless already wearing other armor. This shell does not impare movement, and its weight after application is negligible.

The shell is magical in nature, and is very short lived after the vast amount of power expended to create the shell, lasting 10 minutes before it withers and dies, falling off the skin in flakes (while technically edible, these fungus flakes are less appealing than hard tack).
An effect that dispells or negates magic, such as an antimagic field, causes the fungus to wither and die early.
Basic Crafting Formula:

items: 50bxp
1 hour/day, 3 days downtime
The Barkskin spell, cast each day
10gp of fungi, fertilizers, or other similar ingredients

entries: A rather uninvolved process, the growth is planted and enchanted on the first day, then largely let alone (in a dark area) to grow until the following day. On each of the subsequent days, the growth is pruned, enchanted, has fertilizers and such reapplied, and is generally pampered to grow in the desired manner. While in dim light, the growth grows at half the standard rate. If left in bright light for over 1 day, it dies, wasting spent ingredients.

Once harvested, the light requirements become irrelevant as the enchantments laid upon it at harvest make it more resilient in addition to the glass of the usual jar blocking most of the harmful radiation from the light.

item.name: Nose Candy
entries: This packet of fine crystals can be snorted by a creature as an action.
When snorted, the user gains 1 temporary hit point which lasts for 1 minute. While they have this temporary health they add 1d4 damage to all melee attacks of the same type as the attack.

item.name: Bandana of Speed
entries: While attuned to this devilishly stylish red bandana, a creature may take a second reaction or bonus action each round (action type chosen on attunement).

item.name: Candy Apple (Tainted)
entries: A Candy Apple is consumed as a bonus action, and is beneficial to Candy, but detrimental to all other creatures.
A Candy which consumes a Candy Apple regains 1d8 hit points
Another creature which consumes a Candy Apple falls unconscious (by magical means) for 1 hour, or until it takes damage or is woken as an action by another creature.
Con save DC 18, no effect.

item.name: Gingerbreadman Cookies (Tainted)
entries: Gingerbreadman Cookies are consumed as a bonus action, and are beneficial to Candy, but detrimental to all other creatures.
A Candy which consumes Gingerbreadman Cookies gains the benefits of the {@spell Mirror Image|PHB} spell.

Another creature which consumes Gingerbreadman Cookies is immediately ill and regurgitates a {@creature Swarm of Insects|PHB|Swarm of Gingerbread Men} (except the creature type is Candy (Humanoid), instead of Beast and the attacks deal Bludgeoning damage, instead of Piercing damage.)
Con save DC 18, the swarm is spawned at half health.

item.name: Hot Cocoa (Tainted)
entries: Hot Cocoa is consumed as a bonus action, and is beneficial to Candy, but detrimental to all other creatures.
A Candy which consumes Hot Cocoa gains the benefits of the {@spell Haste|PHB} spell until the beginning of its next turn. It does not suffer the spell ending downside.
Another creature which consumes Hot Cocoa takes 4d4 fire damage.
Con save DC 18, half damage.

item.name: Pie (Tainted)
entries: A Pie is consumed as a bonus action (full action by Candy), and is beneficial to Candy, but detrimental to all other creatures.
A Candy which consumes a Pie regains all of its hit points.
Another creature which consumes a Pie becomes violently ill. It is {@condition stunned} until the start of its next turn, and {@condition poisoned} until the start of the turn after that.
Con save DC 18, the creature is not stunned, and is only poisoned for 1 round.

item.name: Lightbringer
entries: This spear has a magical +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls.
When thrown, the spear has the following benefits:

items: Its damage dice are 2d6 radiant, instead of 1d6(/1d8) piercing.
It ignores 1/2 and 3/4 cover.
It does not suffer from being thrown at disadvantage range.
It instantly returns to hand upon hitting or missing a target.

entries: When thrown it appears to be a line of light streaking straight towards the target, rather than a spear being thrown.

item.name: Water of Refreshment
entries: A single dose (1 bottle) of this shining, clear water can be consumed as an action, instantly granting the benefits of a short rest to the drinker.

item.name: Sword of Shrieking Spirits
entries: The blade of this sword is wreathed in writhing translucent white-blue fragments of a spirit.
When this sword strikes a creature concentrating on a spell, it deals an additional xd6 necrotic damage, where x is the level of the spell being concentrated on.
For one minute after being hit by this sword, the next time the target casts a spell, it must succeed on a concentration check (against original hit damage) or the spell fails.

item.name: Repulsion Grenade
entries: There are 2 major types of repulsion grenades, arcane and alchemical. The damage dice for alchemical grenades are 2d4 fire, for arcane: 1d6 force. The effects are otherwise identical, though preparations differ.

When used, make a ranged attack roll with an improvised weapon (DC 12) to target a square within range (20/60). On a failed check, roll a d4, moving the target square 1 space in a cardinal direction determined by the roll. If this was made at disadvantage, reroll the d4, moving the target square an additional space (if it would move back to the original target, instead move it the opposite direction)

The repulsion grenade affects the targeted square and all adjacent squares. Creatures in the area take damage based on the grenade type and must make a Str saving throw or be thrown 10 feet away from the grenade. (on a sucessful check to throw, the thrower chooses the direction of the center square. On a failed check, the center square is pushed away from the original target square).

entries.name: Arcane Crafting Formula

items: 20gp of arcane alchemical reagents
minimum 2 days downtime
Thunderwave or another spell which repells creatures, cast each day

entries: Arcane repulsion grenades must be primed prior to use. A first level spell slot can prime 3 grenades, with 2 additional grenades being primed for each level above first. Grenades remain primed for 1 day, or until the primer completes a long rest.
Arcane repulsion grenades use the Spell Save DC of the primer.

entries.name: Alchemical Crafting Formula:

items: 25gp of volatile alchemical reagents
minimum 2 days downtime

A successful DC 12 Intelligence (Alchemist's Tools) check. Failing this check by 5 or more causes a minor explosion, dealing 2d4 fire damage to the crafter and any other creatures/objects within 5 feet.

entries: Alchemical grenades use your alchemist's DC (Alchemist's Tools (+2 for expertise) + Int)

An alchemical repulsion grenade remains stable for 1 month, after which is has a 50% chance to detonate while being handled/thrown. It can be safely disposed of using alchemists tools, though no resources may be salvaged.

entries.name: Learning the Formula:
entries: Through research and trial and error, each of these formulae can be discovered. It takes 5 breakthroughs to discover each formula.
For 1 month of downtime spent researching, make a DC 15 Intelligence (Alchemist's Tools) check. Gain 1 breakthrough on a success, and an additional one for every 5 you beat the DC by (20, 25, etc)
A reasonable source of inspiration for this research can yield advantage, or even a flat bonus, to these research checks.

item.name: Pain
entries: Pain is wielded by the goblin Geebrix on the Candyland level of the Dungeon of the Mad Mage.
Pain is a Small severed arm, with crimson rock candy forming bones, and red gummi composing the rest of the arm.
While weilding Pain, you gain a +2 bonus to spell attack rolls and to the saving throw DCs of your warlock spells.
Whenever you cast a spell with Pain, suffer 1d8 damage (potentially breaking concentration). A non-evil creature instead suffers 2d6 damage.
Once per Long Rest, you may cast {@spell Power Word Stun|PHB} using Pain and no spell slot or components.

item.name: Tankard of Many Colors
entries: This copper tankard contains a semi-transparent creamy liquid which shimmers along every hue of the rainbow at a moderate value and saturation. The tankard holds 4 charges.
One or more charges may be drunk as an Action. When this is done, consult the panels below to determine what happens. Do not view the panels before they become relevant.

entries.name: 1 Charge
entries: Choose one of the following effects:
You cast Disguise Self targeting a creature in range of touch. The Investigation DC of this spell is 17, if the creature is unwilling, the save to negate this effect is a DC 17 Wisdom saving throw.
You cast Color Spray as a second level spell. You may alter the target area to be a cone of size 10' to size 20'.

entries.name: 2-3 Charges
entries: Choose one of the following effects:

You cast Mirror Image on a creature you touch with the following change: Instead of 3 images, there are 6. Each image, as well as the targeted creature, are a major hue of the rainbow. Instead of having a chance to cause an attack to miss, each surviving image grants a stacking +1 bonus to AC, with an image being destroyed whenever an attack misses the target, regardless of the hit roll.

You cast Major Image, not requiring concentration. Upon creation of the image you may give it simple animation instructions, such as to walk along a specified route appearing to patrol a hall, but cannot control the image after creating it. If 3 charges were consumed, the image lasts until dispelled. The Investigation DC for this image is 17.

entries.name: 4 Charges
entries: You cast Prismatic Spray, except the target area is a 25' diameter sphere centered on you. The spell hits you. The save DC for the spell is 17.

spell.name: Conjure Fireball

m.text: An empty drinking vessel capable of containing at least 8floz (1 cup)

entries: Crafted by the wizard Kalabash
You conjure 8floz a magical alcohol known as Fireball into an empty vessel that you touch.

Fireball has a unique magical property of turning non-magical water-based liquids that it comes into contact with into Fireball of a weaker concentration. This process converts half the original volume of Fireball of other liquid before losing this magical property and becoming a relatively stable substance at nearly 100% alcohol content.
Fireball tastes faintly of whiskey spiced with cinnamon, but this flavor has been overpowered by the overconcentration of alcohol.
Half a cup of Fireball contains enough nutrients to sustain a creature for 1 day.
A creature takes 1d4 fire damage when consuming undiluted Fireball for the first floz consumed, and every 2 additional floz consumed. This resets after 1 hour of not partaking.
The {@item Alcohol|HB} DC of undiluted fireball is 1 DC 25 check per 2oz
